https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2020/05/14/on-location-balvenie/Now situated inside Balvenie's tasting room we try the core range, a range which shows off the wood finishes that Balvenie's master distiller Dave Stewart has been utilising for decades. These were initially tasted blind, revealed one at a time. First up, a classic.N: This has to be the Doublewood, one of the most consistent malts around. It smells as always, like a soft fluffed-up malty pillow with a soft sour-sweet yeasty citrus profile.T: Sweet and floury-fluffy popcorn-like honey malt with a super-soft [Egyptian] cotton mouthfeel.F: Soft comforting dry and not a hint of astringency.C: This is right up there with the best batches I've had in the last 15 years. This is my benchmark for Balvenie's contemporary distillery profile.

reviews.content: Note by Serge Valentin from whiskyfun.com:Balvenie 12 yo 'DoubleWood' (40%, OB, +/-2015) An expression that we like to follow every two or three years. Now’s the time. Colour: gold. Nose: fine, easy, relatively earthy, with raisins, malt, a touch of PX, and drops of cough syrup. A little honey as well, high-honey-content gingerbread, but rather less oranges than usual. Mouth: very malty, then raisiny, with a little earthy oak and natural chocolate (no supermarket junk by multinationals… err… excuse me). Enjoy this leafiness as well. Finish: short, but pleasantly grassy/oaky and malty. Ovaltine and green tea. Coffee in the aftertaste. Comments: strictly nothing to complain about, and last time I checked, the price was fair. Perhaps is this expression becoming a little drier, having said that. SGP:451 – 80 points.

No power flavour hits and as expected the low ABV presents a low profile, bland, watery but not too unpleasant sherried cask finished whisky. Apples, cinnamon, stewed fruits, caramels, nuts. Good budget quality entry level whisky for beginners. Unfortunately not an integrity whisky as I almost taste the caramel coloring however a well made mass marketed whisky.

I found the Balvenie 14 Rum Cask to be something special, even though, in my opinion, it lacked the rum character. Therefore, my expectation for the 12-year-old was a whisky that would taste similar. Unfortunately, I didn't look closely enough again; I probably thought that a whisky selling for an average of just under 60 euros would surely have an alcohol content of 43% to 46%. How much expectations and reality can diverge... So it has 40% ABV, well, Kavalan can produce a decent whisky with these specifications... Balvenie unfortunately can't with this one. With an average rating of 83, I wasn't expecting a flavor sensation, but in my opinion, it doesn't even come close to that score. You also can't really tell it's 12 years old, even though it doesn't taste young.
